block.p: Preservationists and state officials cheered this month as International Paper agreed to sell them a large wooded property called Treetops, to be conserved as open space. But now a New York City developer that had planned to build luxury homes on the site is suing the company over the sale.

Preservationists and state officials cheered this month as International Paper agreed to sell them a large wooded property called Treetops, to be conserved as open space. But now a New York City developer that had planned to build luxury homes on the site is suing the company over the sale.

In the lawsuit, filed Tuesday in State Superior Court here, the developer, Brickman Associates, said it had agreed to buy the property for $15 million and it accused International Paper of backing out of the deal.
The Treetops property, a 110-acre plot that includes a 33-room house, was once owned by the torch singer and actress Libby Holman, who died in 1971.
The property is in a watershed area considered rich in natural resources.

Last week, International Paper announced that it had agreed to sell the site to the Trust for Public Land, a nonprofit conservation group, in a deal that also involved the state and the municipalities of Greenwich and Stamford.
